Getting started with reportfactory

Source: vignettes/gettingstarted.Rmd
gettingstarted.Rmd

reportfactory is a lightweight R package which facilitates a workflow for compiling multiple .Rmd reports using rmarkdown::render() within a folder.

Basic workflow

  1. create a new factory using new_factory() and move into this new folder

  2. go to report_sources/, write your .Rmd report, using the provided examples as inspiration; remove the examples files; make sure you use the naming conventions explained above, e.g. foobar_2018-01-25.Rmd.

  3. check your report by compiling the .Rmd manually if needed, e.g. rmarkdown::render("foobar_2018-01-25.Rmd"); once you are happy with the results, make sure you remove all output files from the source folder

  4. run update_reports() to generate all outputs, or compile_report("foobar_2018-01-25") if you just want to produce time-stamped outputs for this report; check results in the folder report_outputs

Example workflow

Step 1 - Create a new factory

Create and open a new factory. Here, we create the factory with a default template but stay in our current activities (set move_in to TRUE to switch projects). Check out more templates at reconhub/report_factories_templates.

library(reportfactory)
factory_proj <- "new_factory"
new_factory(file.path(factory_proj), include_template = TRUE, move_in = FALSE)
#> [1] "new_factory"

Step 2 - Add your reports

Here we’ve already created some with the include_template being set to TRUE (the default). The helper functions below show the state of the factory.

list_reports(factory_proj)
#> [1] "example_report_2019-01-31.Rmd"
list_outputs(factory_proj)
#> character(0)
list_deps(factory = factory_proj) # list all needed packages
#> [1] "here"

Option 1 - A single report

The compile_report() function can be used to compile a report using its name, or a partial match for its name. This is useful when you’re actively working on developing a single report.

compile_report("example_report_2019-01-31.Rmd", factory = factory_proj, quiet = TRUE)

Use helper functions to see progress.

list_outputs(factory_proj)
#> character(0)

Option 2 - All reports with updates

Compile all reports to get their outputs. By default, this just compiles the most recent versions.

update_reports(factory_proj)
#> 
#> /// compiling report: 'example_report_2019-01-31'
#> 
#> /// 'example_report_2019-01-31' done!
list_outputs(factory_proj)
#> [1] "example_report_2019-01-31/compiled_2020-11-17_05-43-46/example_report_2019-01-31.html"

Option 3 - All reports

Compile all reports to get their outputs. By default, this just compiles the most recent versions.

update_reports(factory_proj, all = TRUE)
#> 
#> /// compiling report: 'example_report_2019-01-31'
#> 
#> /// 'example_report_2019-01-31' done!
list_outputs(factory_proj)
#> [1] "example_report_2019-01-31/compiled_2020-11-17_05-43-46/example_report_2019-01-31.html"
#> [2] "example_report_2019-01-31/compiled_2020-11-17_05-43-48/example_report_2019-01-31.html"
